lesson.name: Lesson 7.9: Standard Form and Factored Form

page.title: 7.9.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will draw and interpret area diagrams and use the distributive property to write quadratic equations in factored and standard forms.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Rewrite quadratic expressions given in factored form in standard form using either the distributive property or a diagram.
  • Know the difference between “factored form” and “standard form.”

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.9.1: Solving Equations Using Opposite Operations
  • 7.9.2: Finding Products of Differences
    • 7.9.2: Self Check
    • 7.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.9.3: Standard and Factored Forms of Quadratic Expressions
    • 7.9.3: Self Check
    • 7.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.9.4: Expressions in Standard Form

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.9.5: Practice
  • 7.9.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.9.1: Solving Equations Using Opposite Operations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Solve each equation mentally. Then, enter your answer to check it.

  1. \(40-8=40+n\)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(– 8\)

The correct answer is \(– 8\).

  1. \(25+-100=25-n\)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(100\)

The correct answer is \(100\).

  1. \(-3- \frac {1}{2}=3+ \frac {1}{2}n\)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(– 13\)

The correct answer is \(– 13\).

  1. \(72-n=72+6\)

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(– 6\)

The correct answer is \(– 6\).

page.title: 7.9.2: Finding Products of Differences
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Show that \((x-1)(x-1)\) and \(x^2-2x+1\) are equivalent expressions by drawing a diagram or applying the distributive property. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Drawing a Diagram:


 

\(x\)

\(-1\)

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(-x\)

\(-1\)

\(-x\)

\(1\)

The sum of the partial products are \(x^2+-x+-x+1\) or \(x^2-2x+1\).

Applying the Distributive Property:

Applying the distributive property to \((x-1)(x-1)\) gives \(x^2+x \cdot (-1)+(-1) \cdot x+(-1)^2= x^2-x-x+1=x^2-2x+1\).


  1. For each expression, write an equivalent expression. Show your reasoning.
    1. \((x+1)(x-1)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2-1\). For example, applying the distributive property to \((x+1)(x-1)\) gives \(x^2+x-x-1\), which equals \(x^2-1\).

    1. \((x-2)(x+3)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2+x-6\), because \((x+3)(x-2)=x^2-2x+3x-6=x^2+x-6\).

Or using a diagram:


 

\(x\)

\(3\)

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(3x\)

\(-2\)

\(-2x\)

\(-6\)

Adding the partial products in the four sub-rectangles gives \(x^2+3x+-2x+-6\), which equals \(x^2+x-6\).

    1. \((x-2)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2-4x+4\), because \((x-2)(x-2)=x^2-2x-2x+4=x^2-4x+4\).


Video: Finding Products of Differences

Watch the following video to learn more about finding products of differences.

page.title: 7.9.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following expressions is equivalent to \((x-2)^2\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the square of the first and last term. Remember \((x-2)^2=(x-2)(x-2)\). Distribute to multiply the binomials. The answer is \(x^2-4x+4\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the square of the first and last term. Remember \((x-2)^2=(x-2)(x-2)\). Distribute to multiply the binomials. The answer is \(x^2-4x+4\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: Multiply \((x-2)(x-2)\) and distribute. The answer becomes \(x^2-2x-2x+4\). Combining like terms gives \(x^2-4x+4\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Watch the signs when multiplying. \((x-2)(x-2)\) equals \(x^2-2x-2x+4\). The answer is \(x^2-4x+4\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.9.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Multiplying Binomials with Negative Numbers

In a previous lesson, you learned how to square a binomial.

\((a+b)^2=a^2+2ab+b^2\) and \((a-b)^2=a^2-2ab+b^2\)

You can use this to solve the following example.

Example 1

Find the expression equivalent to \((x-3)^2\).

This means to multiply \((x-3)\) by \((x-3)\). So, \((x-3)^2=(x-3)(x-3)\).

Now, distribute. Remember, you can use FOIL.

Distribute the \(x\) to the second binomial, then distribute the \(– 3\) to the second binomial.

Then, combine like terms.

The expression becomes \(x^2-3x-3x+9=x^2-6x+9\).

Example 2

Find the expression equivalent to \((x-4)(x+2)\).

First, distribute. Remember, you can use FOIL.

Multiply the \(x\) by \((x+2)\), then multiply the \(– 4\) by \((x+2)\) and combine like terms:

\(x^2+2x-4x-8=x^2-2x+8\).

Try It: Multiplying Binomials with Negative Numbers

Find the expression equivalent to \((x+5)(x-3)\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find an equivalent expression:

Distribute the \(x\) to \((x-3)\), and then distribute the \(5\) to \((x-3)\). Remember, you can use FOIL.

\(x^2-3x+5x-15\)

Next, combine like terms.

\(x^2+2x-15\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.9.3: Standard and Factored Forms of Quadratic Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

The quadratic expression \(x^2+4x+3\) is written in standard form.

Here are some other quadratic expressions. The expressions on the left are written in standard form and the expressions on the right are not.

Written in standard form:

Not written in standard form:

\(x^2-1\)

\((2x+3)x\)

\(x^2+9x\)

\((x+1)(x-1)\)

\(\frac {1}{2}x^2\)

\(3(x-2)^2+1\)

\(4x^2-2x+5\)

\(-4(x^2+x)+7\)

\(3x^2-x+6\)

\((x+8)(-x+5)\)

  1. What are some characteristics of expressions in standard form?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

  • The standard form always starts with an \(x^2\) term and is in decreasing order of degree.
  • It does not need to have an \(x\) term or a numerical term.
  • Standard form is \(ax^2+bx+c\) where \(a\) is not zero.
  • It also is not important in which order the terms are listed.
  • The standard form shows a sum or difference of terms.

  1. \((x+1)(x-1)\) and \((2x+3)x\) in the right column are quadratic expressions written in factored form. Why do you think that form is called factored form?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

It is a product of two factors. Each factor could be a variable, a number, or an expression with a variable (with no exponent) and a number.


Extending Your Thinking


Which quadratic expression can be described as being both standard form and factored form? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x^2\) could be viewed as both standard and factored. It has an \(x^2\) term even though there is not a constant or linear term. It can also be written as the product of two linear expressions because \(x^2\) is equal to \(x \cdot x\).

page.title: 7.9.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following expressions is a quadratic expression written in standard form?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This expression does not have an \(x^2\) term. The answer is \(x^2-9x+20\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: This expression leads with an \(x^2\) term and is in standard form.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is in factored form. The answer is \(x^2-9x+20\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is not in the form \(ax^2+bx+c\). The answer is \(x^2-9x+20\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.9.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Standard Form of Quadratics

Examples of Standard Form Quadratics

\(x^2\)

\(x^2-9\)

\(x^2-3x\)

\(x^2+4x-45\)

These examples have an \(x^2\) and lead with it. Some have an \(x\) term or a constant term but it is not needed to be in standard form. Standard form of a quadratic expression is of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\), where \(a \neq 0\).

Non-Examples of Standard Form Quadratics

\(7-x\)

\(9(x-2)\)

\(x(x+10)\)

These examples do not have an \(x^2\) term.

Try It: Standard Form of Quadratics

Determine if \(4x(x-2)\) is a quadratic in standard form.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine if the expression is in standard form:

This expression is in factored form. If the \(4x\) is distributed, the expression becomes \(4x^2-8x\), which is in standard form.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.9.4: Expressions in Standard Form
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

For each expression, write an equivalent expression in standard form. Show your reasoning.

  1. \((2x+5)(x+1)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(2x^2+7x+5\). The diagram shows that\((2x+5)(x+1)=2x \cdot x+2x \cdot 1+5 \cdot x+5 \cdot 1\). Adding this together gives \(2x^2+7x+5\) in standard form.


 

\(2x\)

\(5\)

\(x\)

\(2x^2\)

\(5x\)

\(1\)

\(2x\)

\(5\)

  1. \((x-2)(x+2)\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2-4\). \((x+2)(x-2)=x^2+(-2x)+2x+(-4)=x^2-4\).The diagram also shows that \((x+2)(x-2)=x^2-4\).


 

\(x\)

\(2\)

\(x\)

\(x^2\)

\(2x\)

\(-2\)

\(-2x\)

\(-4\)

page.title: 7.9.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Choose the standard form of the quadratic expression.
      1. \((x+4)(x-1)\)

Correct! \(x^2+3x-4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.9.3 and 7.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(x^2+3x-4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. \((2x-1)(3x-1)\)

Correct! \(6x^2-5x+1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.9.3 and 7.9.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(6x^2-5x+1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Consider the expression \(8-6x+x^2\).
    1. Is the expression in standard form?

Correct! No. Even though it has \(x^2\) term, it does not start with the \(x^2\) term.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.9.3 and 7.9.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. Even though it starts with a number and ends with an \(x^2\), it is not of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Is the expression equivalent to \((x-4)(x-2)\)?

Correct! Yes. Applying the distributive property gives \(x^2-2x-4x+8\) or \(x^2-6x+8\), which is equivalent to \(8-6x+x^2\).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.9.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Yes. Applying the distributive property gives \(x^2-2x-4x+8\) or \(x^2-6x+8\), which is equivalent to \(8-6x+x^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the standard form of the quadratic expression \((x-2)(x+8)\). Use the standard form to answer questions a, b, and c.

    1. What is the value of \(a\) in this expression \(ax^2+bx+c\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(a\)=1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(a\)=1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(b\) in this expression \(ax^2+bx+c\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(b\)=6

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(b\)=6. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. What is the value of \(c\) in this expression \(ax^2+bx+c\)?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! \(c=-16\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.9.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(c=-16\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.9.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Rewrite quadratic expressions given in factored form in standard form using either the distributive property or a diagram.
  • Know the difference between “factored form” and “standard form.”

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.9.1: Solving Equations Using Opposite Operations
    • In this activity, you solved equations that involve using inverse operations.
  • 7.9.2: Finding Products of Differences
    • In this activity, you multiplied binomial expressions that involve subtraction.
    • 7.9.2: Self Check
    • 7.9.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.9.3: Standard and Factored Forms of Quadratic Expressions
    • In this activity, you identified if an expression is a quadratic in standard form.
    • 7.9.3: Self Check
    • 7.9.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.9.4: Expressions in Standard Form
    • In this activity, you continued to identify standard quadratic expressions.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.9.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
